repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Mouse shape does not change when hovering over resizable elements.

Solution:

Update the mode when hovering over resizable elements (statusbar and vsep) and set the mshape property. Respond to mode changes in the TUI by updating the mouse shape via the [OSC 22 escape sequence](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/pointer-shapes/#pointer-shape-names)
reference: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21458

TODO:
- [x] vsep mouse cursor doesn't show up on bufload
  - need to do some unintuitive actions like opening a terminal buffer
  - the `mshape` is uninitialized memory
  - `tui_mode_info_set` is called but cursor_shapes is not updated
  - classic use after free
- [x] change mouse cursor on horizontal separators
- [x] support `mouseshape` option
- [ ] should handle conflicts with terminal buffer?
- [ ] query for mouse shape support for which shapes are available?
- [ ] confirm if mshape backwards incompatible(?) change on `mshape` for `mode_info_set` is valid
  - it's a bit awkward otherwise... we could maybe add a mapping between ints and names as an option or add a new field altogether
- [x] respect `used_for` to not change the cursor shape for mouse only modes
  - needed so that the cursor shape is not unexpected when in a mouse only mode
- [x] keep resize cursor _while_ resizing (horizontal flickers, vertical just converts back to default)
  - needed to `setmouse()` after `jump_to_mouse()`
- [ ] get confirmation on the path forward for other elements like links
- [x] differentiate statusline/vsep/hsep hover and drag
- [x] separate mouse mode for hsep
- [x] disable if `mousemoveevent` is `false`
- [ ] update `mouseshape` docs to remove reference to win32

comment_data.body:
I mentioned this [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21458#issuecomment-2575984459), but I don't think we should enforce a static list of shapes since this should work with both GUIs (which do not use the OSC 22 sequence and are thus not constrained by the shapes supported by that protocol) and the TUI.

It's fine to list the shapes here if we mention that these are the shapes _supported by the TUI_, making it clear that this option can contain any arbitrary shape value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4592,6 +4592,68 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 <	Will make Nvim scroll 5 lines at a time when scrolling vertically, and
 	scroll 2 columns at a time when scrolling horizontally.
 
+					*'mouseshape'* *'mouses'* *E547*
+'mouseshape' 'mouses'	string	(default "i-r:beam,s:updown,sd:udsizing,vs:leftright,vd:lrsizing,m:no,ml:up-arrow,v:rightup-arrow")
+			global
+	This option tells Vim what the mouse pointer should look like in
+	different modes.  The option is a comma-separated list of parts, much
+	like used for 'guicursor'.  Each part consist of a mode/location-list
+	and an argument-list:
+		mode-list:shape,mode-list:shape,..
+	The mode-list is a dash separated list of these modes/locations:
+			In a normal window: ~
+		n	Normal mode
+		v	Visual mode
+		ve	Visual mode with 'selection' "exclusive" (same as 'v',
+			if not specified)
+		o	Operator-pending mode
+		i	Insert mode
+		r	Replace mode
+
+			Others: ~
+		c	appending to the command-line
+		ci	inserting in the command-line
+		cr	replacing in the command-line
+		m	at the 'Hit ENTER' or 'More' prompts
+		ml	idem, but cursor in the last line
+		e	any mode, pointer below last window
+		s	any mode, pointer on a status line
+		sd	any mode, while dragging a status line
+		vs	any mode, pointer on a vertical separator line
+		vd	any mode, while dragging a vertical separator line
+		a	everywhere
+
+	The shape is one of the following:
+	avail	name		looks like ~
+	w x	arrow		Normal mouse pointer
+	w x	blank		no pointer at all (use with care!)
+	w x	beam		I-beam
+	w x	updown		up-down sizing arrows
+	w x	leftright	left-right sizing arrows
+	w x	busy		The system's usual busy pointer
+	w x	no		The system's usual "no input" pointer
+	  x	udsizing	indicates up-down resizing
+	  x	lrsizing	indicates left-right resizing
+	  x	crosshair	like a big thin +
+	  x	hand1		black hand
+	  x	hand2		white hand
+	  x	pencil		what you write with
+	  x	question	big ?
+	  x	rightup-arrow	arrow pointing right-up
+	w x	up-arrow	arrow pointing up
+	  x	<number>	any X11 pointer number (see X11/cursorfont.h)

comment_data.body: yep i saw ur comment, that's why the mshape_get_kitty_name helper is only used in tui but not in server, the shape configured by the user will just be sent over

comment_data.body: also these are just the docs from vim i think we'll need to update these, not sure what the practice is tho. i have tried to maintain capatibility there but some things are not in the names that kitty lists (pencil for example)

comment_data.body:
also one other thing, do u know if the core team would prefer i split the pr into a few different ones, or keep it is as is. i was thinking splitting into at minimum 3, but open to whatever's easiest: 
- sending and updating mshape via ui_mode_info_set and mode_set protocols
- parsing and updating mode info and and mode set in the tui client
- parsing the mouse shape option
- optionally splitting out new mode shape for hsep_hover and hsep_drag

comment_regular_data.body: closing this in favor of splitting up prs, first one here https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/37324

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(ui/tui): update and respond to mshape in mode
